abstract: The timing couldn't have been better for the Asian release of "The Lady," a much-anticipated new film about Aung San Suu Kyi. The pro-democracy leader from Myanmar has been freed from house arrest and the government is allowing her to run for Parliament in April elections. The film will be released next month in Singapore and Taiwan, although there is no word on whether it will be shown in mainland China, a close political and economic ally of Myanmar. Not unexpectedly, the film has been banned in Myanmar. When a Hong Kong journalist asked about rumors that the pirated DVD version was already available there, the director Luc Besson responded that that would be "excellent news."
